properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected today. Locations: Bay St. George Deer Lake - Humber Valley parts of central Newfoundland eastern Newfoundland northern Avalon Peninsula. Total snowfall accumulations: 15 to 25 cm. Time span: continuing into this evening. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly 70 to 80 km/h. Remarks: Snow and strong southeasterly winds will result in reduced visibilities in blowing snow at times. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-28T22:59:15-00:00

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Wind chill values near minus 40 are expected beginning Monday and continuing Tuesday. An Arctic air mass combined with moderate winds will cause extreme cold conditions. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T01:39:20-00:00

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow combined with strong northwesterly winds will reduce visibilities to near zero on Monday. ### Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Southerly winds will reach up to 90 kilometres per hour late this evening and overnight tonight. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potentially damaging winds tonight and Monday. Strong northwest winds gusting up to 80 km/h are forecast to develop this evening along the shorelines of northern Lake Huron, northern Georgian Bay and eastern Lake Superior. Winds will then diminish slightly late tonight into Monday morning but are expected to strengthen again Monday afternoon. Gusts up to 80 km/h will be possible Monday afternoon and a Wind Warning may be required tonight and Monday. The winds will diminish Monday evening. Strong winds can throw loose objects, cause tree branches to break, and may cause property damage. Power outages are also possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T01:30:25-00:00

properties.Title: Flash Freeze Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: In the late overnight hours until early Monday morning, the arrival of an Arctic air mass will cause temperatures to fall dramatically, from near zero to minus 16 degrees Celsius in a few hours. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Snowfall with total amounts of 5 to 10 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will affect the area beginning late this morning or early afternoon. Additionally, strong northwest winds gusting up to 60 km/h will develop this evening creating localized areas of blowing snow. Dangerous winter driving conditions due to heavy snow and blowing snow are expected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with the changing road conditions. Conditions are expected to improve by late this evening. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Time span: Monday morning until Tuesday morning. Locations: northern New Brunswick Remarks: snow, heavy at times, will spread eastward across northern New Brunswick beginning early Monday morning. Temperatures will rise above zero in some places Monday afternoon which will cause partial melting of the snow as it falls, which could make it heavy to move. Snow tapers to flurries Tuesday morning then strong northerlies develop which ushers in a very cold airmass. Some blowing snow is possible on Tuesday morning. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T06:30:57-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. From Monday to Tuesday, between 20 and 40 centimetres of snow along with strong winds and blowing snow are expected. Snow at times heavy will start Monday morning. Then during the day, winds reaching up to 80 km/h will cause blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T01:46:24-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T09:47:24-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2616701574.2021

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low in the northern Gulf of Alaska and high pressure over the Northwest Territories are combining to produce a strong pressure gradient over the Dempster highway. Easterly winds to 80 km/h gusting to 100 near the Richardson Mountains are giving blizzard conditions. Winds are forecast to ease tonight. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-28T23:59:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T13:07:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1089797244.2021
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for today. Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. Snow, at times heavy, will affect parts of northeastern Ontario beginning late this morning or early afternoon. Additionally, strong northwest winds gusting up to 70 km/h will develop this evening creating localized areas of blowing snow. Dangerous winter driving conditions due to heavy snow and blowing snow are expected. Be prepared to adjust your driving with the changing road conditions. Conditions are expected to improve by Monday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-03-01T04:35:10-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T12:36:10-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0623719088.2021

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 15 cm is expected. A significant Pacific frontal system continues to give snow to southern Yukon. Snow will ease this morning in Whitehorse, Haines Junction and Teslin. Snow will ease this afternoon in Beaver Creek, Pelly - Carmacks, and Watson Lake. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill values of -45 and colder continue for communities in northern Manitoba this morning. These extreme wind chill values will moderate during the day. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-28T19:59:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-28T10:26:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0294575776.2021
